title: 114_hr3736
content: The "Clatsop-Nehalem Restoration Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. Definitions are provided in Section 2 of the Act. The "Clatsop-Nehalem Restoration Act" defines key terms such as Interim Council, Member, Secretary, Tribal governing body, and Tribe. The Clatsop-Nehalem Confederated Tribes of Oregon are considered as one tribe for Federal recognition, benefits, self-government, and membership roll compilation. Additionally, the Restoration Act restores Federal recognition, rights, and privileges. Federal recognition is extended to the Clatsop-Nehalem Confederated Tribes of Oregon, restoring their rights and privileges under Federal treaties and authorities. This Act does not affect treaty rights of other federally recognized Indian tribes. The Act grants Federal services and benefits to the Clatsop-Nehalem Confederated Tribes of Oregon, including members residing in specific counties. No hunting, fishing, or trapping rights are restored under this Act. No lands in Tillamook County, Oregon shall be held in trust by the United States for the benefit and use of the tribe, as stated in this Act. This Act does not alter any property rights, contractual obligations, or tax levies, unless specifically provided for. SEC. 5. INTERIM COUNCIL. Establishment of an Interim Council of the tribe with nine members to represent and govern the tribe until the tribal governing body convenes. Nomination and election process for Interim Council members to be conducted within specific timeframes set by the Secretary. The Secretary shall conduct a secret ballot election to elect Interim Council members from nominated candidates. Approval of election results is subject to meeting nomination and election requirements. If unsatisfied, another general council meeting will be called within 60 days for new nominations and another election within 45 days. The Interim Council, established through a secret ballot election, has limited powers under the Act. It has the authority to receive grants and enter contracts for Federal services or benefits. The Council will terminate once the tribal governing body convenes, except as specified in subsection (d). The Secretary ensures that all members are notified of meetings and elections at least 10 days in advance. The Interim Council, formed through a secret ballot election, can receive grants and enter contracts for Federal services. It will dissolve once the tribal governing body convenes, except in cases of vacancies. Vacancies are filled through a general council meeting and election, with notice provided to members at least 10 days in advance. The tribal constitution and bylaws govern the tribal governing body. The Interim Council must prepare and adopt a tribal constitution and bylaws within 6 months. After adoption, the Council can request the Secretary to schedule an election to approve or disapprove the constitution and bylaws. The Interim Council must prepare and adopt a tribal constitution and bylaws within 6 months. Not less than 30 days before any election, a copy of the proposed constitution and bylaws shall be sent to each member. Majority vote of those actually voting is necessary for adoption. If the majority does not approve the proposed tribal constitution and bylaws in an election, the Interim Council will prepare a new proposal within 6 months. The new proposal must be adopted by the Interim Council and then voted on by the members. The Interim Council will conduct an election within 120 days of tribal approval to elect the tribal governing body under the new constitution and bylaws, with absentee and write-in voting allowed. SEC. 7. MEMBERSHIP ROLLS; VOTING RIGHTS OF MEMBER. The membership roll of the Clatsop-Nehalem Confederated Tribes is established and open. Eligibility criteria include direct descent from a Clatsop or Nehalem Tillamook Indian on tribal rolls compiled in 1906 or being found eligible by the Portland, Oregon, Area Office of the Bureau of Indian Affairs. The Act of August 24, 1912, Act of August 30, 1964, or part 43 of title 25, Code of Federal Regulations, provide eligibility criteria for membership in the Clatsop-Nehalem Confederated Tribes, including direct descent from signers of treaties with the Clatsop Tribe and the Nehalem Band of the Tillamooks in 1851. The eligibility criteria for membership in the Clatsop-Nehalem Confederated Tribes include direct descent from Clatsop or Nehalem Tillamook Indians, descendants of the Hobsonville Community, and children born to tribe members. After the first election, the constitution and bylaws will govern membership. Dual membership in another federally recognized tribe is not allowed. Verification procedures for eligibility must be followed before the interim council election. Before the election of the Interim Council, descendancy verification and age verification for voting rights must be done before the Secretary. After the Interim Council is elected but before the tribal governing body election, descendancy and age verification can be done before the Interim Council or its representative, with the option to appeal to the Secretary for membership roll exclusion. After the first tribal governing body election, the constitution and bylaws will govern membership verification. The Interim Council and Secretary will transfer enrollment records to the tribal governing body. Membership roll must be published at least 60 days before. The Secretary must publish the tribe's membership roll in the Federal Register at least 60 days before the election. Members 18 years and older have voting rights, including attending meetings, nominating candidates, running for office, and voting in elections for the Interim Council and tribal governing body. The tribe's membership roll must be published in the Federal Register before the election, allowing members 18 years and older to participate in voting rights and elections for the Interim Council and tribal governing body. The Secretary has the authority to create necessary regulations for implementing the Act, and it does not set a precedent for other Indian tribes except the Clatsop-Nehalem Confederated Tribes of Oregon.
